title: 5 hair-raising reasons to see the haunted house in America's oldest penitentiary
text:
Comments 
It's been 25 years since Eastern State Penitentiary — a normally serene, historic site in Philadelphia, Pennsylvania — turned down the lights and turned up the horror for what has become the annual Halloween fundraiser and haunted house, Terror Behind the Walls (TBTW) . 
Located inside a real abandoned prison that has been investigated by many ghost hunters, Terror Behind the Walls has been named one of the country's scariest haunted houses countless times. 
The first year the fundraiser was held, it was only one night, and consisted of guests sitting within the castle-like walls telling ghost stories. 
During its quarter-century history, Terror has grown and changed over the years and now includes an choice to "opt in" and become part of the show, giving guests the most hair-raising experience possible. Terror Behind the Walls 2015 Terror Behind the Walls debuts two new attractions, Oct. 1, 2015. 
Once inside the prison, Terror is broken into six different attractions — Lock Down, Infirmary, Detritus, Machine Shop, and this year's two new sections, Quarantine 4D and Break Out. 
"As you leave Infirmary, you learn of a virus that every visitor will catch," said Amy Hollaman, reative director for Terror Behind the Walls. "Then you enter Quarantine 4D." 
If guests can escape the virus in Quarantine, they then must escape the prison itself through Break Out. 
Here are a few reasons why this haunted attraction is worth the visit this season. A real abandoned prison 
Eastern State Penitentiary, which opened in 1829, has been described as the perfect setting for a haunted attraction. 
With 30-foot, castle-like walls, the prison is like a silent fortress in the otherwise bustling Fairmount Avenue section of Philadelphia. 
In its heyday, Eastern State was a one-of-a-kind, modern marvel, having running water even before the White House. 
But as hundreds of thousands of prisoners moved through the one and only way in and out of the penitentiary, the building began to deteriorate. 
In 1971, Eastern State was completely abandoned. 
Today, the atmosphere only adds to the creepiness of Terror Behind the Walls. MORE : Terror Time: October brings out ghost stories of Eastern State | Paranormal Corner 
Terror visitors walk past — and in some cases get pulled into — the creepy jail cells, the decrepit corridors, and between the crumbling walls. 
Not much needs to be done to turn Eastern State into a haunted attraction, but a team of professional set designers create an entire haunted world inside the stone walls. Looks that scare 
The dilapidated stone walls and rusty bars that cover the meager cells make for a perfect setting for a haunted house. 
It is eerie, but Terror Behind the Walls is more than just a stroll through an abandoned prison. 
The story that unravels through the six attractions takes imagination and creativity to bring to life. 
From the hi-tech lighting and frightening sound track, to the realistic props and enchanting fog machines, guests become immersed in a bizarre world of darkness. 
One example of the artistry that goes into making Terror what it has become is the new Quarantine 4D. 
With the help of black lights and neon paint, the world of Quarantine jumps off the black walls in a glowing apocalypse of designs, props, and the characters who dwell there. Transformations 
Each of the approximately 250 actors who lurk in the cells and corridors of Terror are costumed from head to toe each night. 
Makeup Director Lauren Palmer, along with her team of 14 makeup artists, create zombie prisoners and guards, bloody doctors and nurses, and mythological creatures who glow in the dark to greet guests at every show. 
Costume director Keith Lambert and his assistant outfit every actor with prison scrubs, guard uniforms, even disguises that are designed to blend in with the surroundings so the actor can provide the startling scares visitors are looking for. Creepy characters 'round every corner 
Auditions to be a part of Terror Behind the Walls begin in the summer. 
Long before the first leaf falls, approximately 500 hopeful haunters attend auditions with the dream of becoming a part of the Terror family. 
Many actors return year after year, but a large number are hired seasonally. 
The audition process involves potential monsters screaming, acting out terrorizing scenarios, and personally explaining why they want to be a part of Terror Behind the Walls. MORE : Paranormal Corner: Is there 'terror behind the walls?' 
If chosen to join in the haunt, the actor must choose a name and story for their character to bring that persona to life. 
These actors are paid employees who are trained and, while in the public eye, unwaveringly maintain their character. Actual hauntings 
Ask anyone involved with Terror Behind the Walls if they have ever had a strange experience at the prison, and the answer will most likely be "yes." 
Professional paranormal investigators from SyFy's "Ghost Hunters," to Salem County-based Jersey Unique Minds Paranormal Society, have brought equipment into the prison to see if the claims of hauntings throughout the location can be proven. 
Evidence such as full-bodied apparitions, class A EVPs (electronic voice phenomenon), and reports of physical contact have been recorded within the walls. 
So, when you ascend the staircase during Lock Down, and gaze upon the second level of cellblock 12, be sure to say hello. 
You will be standing in the exact spot where the Ghost Hunters filmed an apparition running past the dark, abandoned cells. 
Terror Behind the Walls is open select days from now through Nov. 7. 
For more information and for tickets, visit www.easternstate.org/halloween .
